TemplateInfo.Name: Summary Statistics - Baseline/Reform
TemplateInfo.Title: Summary Statistics - Baseline vs Reforms
TemplateInfo.Subtitle: Results for [baseCountry]: [baseSys] vs [refSysList]
TemplateInfo.GeneralDescription:
Income concepts:

Market/Original incomes are the sum of income from employment and self-employment plus income from other sources. Other sources include income from investment, property, private pensions, private transfers, children younger than 16, minus private transfers paid to other households. See income list ils_origy in the country models.

Disposable incomes are the sum of market incomes and benefits (incl. pensions) minus taxes and social insurance contributions. See income list ils_dispy in the country models. Equivalised disposable income is the total disposable household income divided by the modified OECD scale to take differences in household composition into account. The modified OECD scale attributes a weight of 1 to the head of the household, a weight of 0.5 to every person above the age of 14 and a weight of 0.3 to every child aged 0-14.

Decile groups are calculated by ranking individuals according to their equivalised disposable household income and dividing them into ten similar-sized groups.

All monetary amounts – except for the fiscal overview – are presented in average monthly amounts and in the currency defined in the Euromod output file.

Poverty indicators:

Households are defined as being at risk of poverty (poor) if their equivalised disposable household income is below the poverty line. The poverty line is defined as 60% of the country specific median equivalised disposable household income. The poverty gap is the difference between the poverty line and the median income of people at-risk-of poverty divided by the poverty line. The median income of people at-risk-of poverty is based on equivalised disposable income.

NOTE: negative equivalised disposable household incomes are recoded to 0 for all poverty related results.

Inequality indicators:

Gini measures the distribution of income within a country where 0 means perfect income equality and 1 means perfect income inequality.

The S80/20 ratio - also referred to as the income quintile share ratio – is the ratio of the total income received by the 20% of the population with the highest income to that received by the bottom 20%.

NOTE: negative incomes are recoded to 0 for results on Gini and S80/20 indicators.

Definition of age-groups:

Sub-population groups are defined as follows:

·    Children are persons aged 18 or younger

·    Working Age are persons older than 18 up to the age of 64

·    Someone is economically active if he/she has income from employment or self-employment

·    Elderly are persons aged 65 or older

Page.Name: FiscalOverview
Page.Title: Market Incomes and Government Revenue && Expenditure
Page.Subtitle: Yearly, mill., currency as defined in EM output
Page.Description:
The table shows total annual amounts of the specified tax-benefit system(s). It provides an overview of market incomes as well as government revenue and expenditure covered in EUROMOD.

The aggregated amount for “other social insurance contributions” is already included in “employee social insurance contributions” in all EM versions released before 2018.

Results refer to the following income lists:

  • Total market incomes: ils_origy
  • Income from (self) employment: ils_earns
  • Other market incomes: ils_origy minus ils_earns
  • Government revenue through taxes and social insurance contributions are the sum of:
    • Direct taxes: ils_tax
    • Employee social insurance contributions: ils_sicee
    • Self-employed social insurance contributions: ils_sicse
    • Other social insurance contributions: ils_sicot
    • Employer social insurance contributions (not part of disposable income): ils_sicer
  • Credited social insurance contributions (not part of disposable income): ils_sicct
  • Government expenditure on social transfers: ils_ben
    Which is the sum of:
    • Unemployment benefits: ils_b1_bun
    • Family and education benefits: ils_b2_bfaed
    • Social assistance and housing benefits: ils_b2_bsaho
    • Pensions, health and disability benefits: ils_b2_penhl
    As well as the sum of:
    • Means-tested non-pension benefits: ils_benmt
    • Non-means-tested non-pension benefits: ils_bennt
    • Pensions: ils_pen

Row.Name: Government revenue through taxes and social insurance contributions
... employer social insurance contributions (not part of disposable income)
Credited social insurance contributions (not part of disposable income)

Page.Name: Poverty
Page.Title: Basic Poverty Indices
Page.Description:
The table shows the poverty risk of the total population and different sub-population groups.

The poverty line (but not the poverty status) is based on the base scenario for the baseline and reform results.

Column.Title:
Poverty Risk for
[baseSys] (base)
Column.Name: Poverty Risk for baseSys
Column.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income lower than 60% of the country specific median income.

ReformColumn.Name: Poverty Risk for refSys
ReformColumn.Title:
Poverty Risk for
[refSys]
ReformColumn.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income lower than 60% of the country specific median income.

CellAction.FormulaString: (REF_COL[Poverty Risk for refSys] - BASE_COL[Poverty Risk for baseSys]) * 100

Row.Name: Fixed Poverty Line
Row.Tooltip: 60% of the country specific median equivalised disposable household income.

Page.Name: Inequality
Page.Title: Basic Inequality Indices
Page.Description:
The table shows the Gini index and S80/20 indicator for selected income concepts:

·   The comparison of the original income with the original income after taxes shows to what extent taxes contribute to redistribution.

·   The comparison of the original income plus public pensions after taxes with the original income after taxes shows the role of public pensions for redistribution.

·   The comparison of the original income with the disposable income shows the extent of income redistribution performed by the tax-benefit systems as a whole (incl. social insurance contributions and benefits beyond public pensions).

All the indexes are calculated within each scenario, with no connection to the other scenarios. All are income-concept-specific; however, the allocation of observations of the top and bottom 20% is always based on disposable income.

Column.Title:

ReformColumn.Title:

S80/S20
[refSys]
ReformColumn.Tooltip: Ratio of total income received top quintile to that received by bottom quintile.

Row.Name: Original Income
Row.Tooltip: Earnings from employment and self-employment plus other market incomes (from investment, property, private pensions, private transfers, children younger than 16) minus private transfers paid to other households.

Row.Name: Original Income after Taxes/SIC
Row.Tooltip: Original income – Taxes – Social Insurance Contributions.

Row.Name: Original Income incl. Public Pensions after Taxes/SIC
Row.Tooltip: Original income + Public Pensions – Taxes – Social Insurance Contributions.

Row.Name: Disposable Income
Row.Tooltip: Original income + Benefits (incl. Public Pensions) – Taxes – Social Insurance Contributions.

Page.Name: MeanIncome
Page.Title: Mean household income by decile groups
Page.Description:
The table shows the mean household income of decile groups. The last two rows show the mean income of the total population (All) and the population at-risk-of-poverty (Poor).

While the calculation of the decile groups is based on equivalised income, the reported mean incomes refer to non-equivalised household results. The decile group and poverty status are based on the base scenario. The reform results show how income changes within each group (people are not moving from one group to the other).

Row.Name: Poor
Row.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income lower than 60% of the country specific median income.

Page.Name: MeanEqIncome
Page.Title: Mean equivalised income by decile groups
Page.Description:
The table shows the mean equivalised income of decile groups. The last two rows show the mean income of the total population (All) and the population at-risk-of-poverty (Poor).

The calculation of the decile groups and the reported mean incomes is based on equivalised incomes. The decile groups and the poverty status are based on the base scenario. The reform results show how income changes within each group (people are not moving from one group to the other).

Row.Name: Poor
Row.Tooltip: Equivalised disposable household income lower than 60% of the country specific median income.

Page.Name: Metadata
Page.Title: Metadata
Page.Description: The table shows information on the execution: run system, dataset, output file name, add-ons and extensions selected, execution start time, execution end time and execution duration.
